author: The Australian
title: Facebook pioneer joins Whole New Home | The
text:
Matt Hehman, who was in charge of Facebook’s Australian operations, will serve as non-executive director alongside existing board members Neil Patel, Tony King, Nathan Sellyn and another former Facebook executive, Nik Ajagu.
Mr Hehman began his career with Facebook in 2005 where he played a key role in the monetisation strategy of the business and was a core member of the management team that oversaw the implementation of Microsoft’s investment in Facebook’s advertising.
Whole New Home is hoping to use Mr Hehman’s experience around monetisation models within the software-as-service (SaaS) space to help fuel its home renovations online platform which connects home designers directly with homeowners and tenants.
According to Mr Hehman, he first decided to get involved with WNH after going through the process of decorating his own home.
“It became clear (to me) that there’s a gap in technical support for the interior designer community and empowering them through technology is a worthwhile mission,” he told The Australian.
“Given the lack in technology specifically built for interior designers, it’s going to be a challenge educating the community on how to use it, but also for WNH to understand what designers want.”
According to Hehman, his experience in bringing a new product to market puts him a good position to confront these challenges.
“I’ve been very fortunate to have seen Facebook grow from its early days, and because of the company’s culture of transparency, I was exposed to a variety of challenges ranging from hiring and HR, to user growth and monetisation.”
Mr Hehman is also an active investor in tech start-ups, both in the United States and in Australia, with stakes in Expert360, Bountye and the start-up foundry, Digital4ge. One of his US investments, Lookflow, was acquired by Yahoo in 2013.
He said that Australia has a ‘strong start-up scene’ with talented engineers and great ideas who just need a little funding to get off the ground.
“I’ve met a lot of passionate founders and investors that simply want to make useful products that further people’s lives. A lot of the focus and passion reminds me of Silicon Valley circa 2005, when it was a smaller community than it is today. The biggest challenge for the Australian tech scene surrounds funding and being competitive with other markets where there are bigger funds willing to take larger risks.”
The WNH platform currently has more than 40,000 home decor products (up to 500,000 next year) and 340 interior designers, and expects rapid development and expansion of its home decor inventory, interior designer partners and customer base. One feature of the platform is called ‘Design Studios’ where home designers and customers can create a 3D holographic image of each room in their house, allowing users to decorate, interact and walk around the image.
